results.headline: Review: ‘Get a Job’ Portrays Work as an Object of Ambivalent Desire
results.summary_short: Miles Teller stars in this episodic comedy as a young man whose girlfriend doesn’t think he’s serious enough about his low-level corporate work.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Get a Job

results.headline: Review: ‘My Big Fat Greek Wedding 2’ Is Something Tired, Something New
results.summary_short: This long-awaited sequel to the hit romantic comedy, again written by and starring Nia Vardalos, is a washed-out recycling of ethnic clichés and exhausted jokes.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Big Fat Greek Wedding 2

results.display_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice
results.headline: Review: ‘Batman v Superman’ ... v Fun?
results.summary_short: The film, pitting Ben Affleck against Henry Cavill, largely serves as an extended trailer for a slate of coming DC Comics movies like “Wonder Woman.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice

results.headline: Review: ‘Kapoor & Sons’ Centers on an Indian Family’s Flaws
results.summary_short: This film, directed by Shakun Batra, features comedy, drama, money troubles and at least one secret.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kapoor & Sons — Since 1921

results.headline: Review: In ‘The Confirmation,’ a Troubled Father and Tender Son Bond
results.summary_short: This Bob Nelson character study stars Clive Owen as a troubled handyman who has more than stolen tools on his mind.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Confirmation

results.headline: Review: In ‘Sweet Bean,’ a Delicacy Unites a Vendor and an Old Woman
results.summary_short: A middle-aged Japanese cook who sells dorayaki from a stall without much enthusiasm awakens to life’s complexity when he takes on a much older assistant.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sweet Bean

results.headline: Review: ‘Everything Is Copy,’ a Son’s Tribute to Nora Ephron
results.summary_short: Celebrities and family members discuss and honor Ephron’s tartness in this documentary from Jacob Bernstein.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Everything Is Copy

results.headline: Review: ‘Krisha,’ a Family Drama Set Around Thanksgiving
results.summary_short: A house in Texas becomes the site of a woman’s undoing in Trey Edward Shults’s film.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Krisha

results.headline: Review: In ‘My Golden Days,’ Aching for a Love Left Behind
results.summary_short: Arnaud Desplechin’s film tells of a middle-aged anthropologist and the women who left their imprint on different stages of his life.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Golden Days

results.headline: Review: ‘Take Me to the River’ Immerses a Teenager in Scandal at a Family Reunion
results.summary_short: A gay California teenager who must closet his sexuality at a gathering in Nebraska suddenly finds himself a target of suspicion.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Take Me to the River

results.headline: Review: ‘The Brainwashing of My Dad’ Examines the Influence of Right-Wing News Media
results.summary_short: This documentary by Jen Senko shows how her father became what she considers a casualty of the most conservative elements of the media.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Brainwashing of My Dad

results.headline: Review: In ‘The Preppie Connection,’ Drug Smuggling at an Elite School
results.summary_short: This film is inspired by events in 1984 at Choate Rosemary Hall in Connecticut, where a student was accused of smuggling cocaine to sell to classmates.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Preppie Connection

results.headline: Review: In ‘Ktown Cowboys,’ Men on the Prowl in Koreatown
results.summary_short: Based on a popular web series, the film follows characters sampling various kinds of night life in Los Angeles as grown-up problems hover.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ktown Cowboys

results.headline: Review: In ‘The Birth of Sake,’ a Brew Made With Pride and Lots of Patience
results.summary_short: Erik Shirai’s documentary opens a window into the unhurried and elaborate making of the Japanese liquor at a family-owned brewery.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Birth of Sake

results.headline: Review: In ‘The Bronze,’ a Former Gymnast Has Losing Ways
results.summary_short: Melissa Rauch stars in this comedy about an Olympic medalist who is defined by her spitefulness and jealousy.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Bronze

results.headline: Review: ‘A Space Program’ Adds Whimsy to a Mission to Mars
results.summary_short: Van Neistat’s film is the record of the artist Tom Sachs’s installation that amused audiences at the Park Avenue Armory in 2012.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Space Program

results.headline: Review: ‘The Program,’ a Docudrama on the Fall of Lance Armstrong
results.summary_short: In this Stephen Frears film, Ben Foster plays Armstrong, the cyclist disgraced and stripped of victories after a doping scandal.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Program

results.headline: Review: ‘Thank You for Playing’ Is About Making ‘That Dragon, Cancer’
results.summary_short: This documentary records the efforts of a video game programmer to create a game, “That Dragon, Cancer,” inspired by his son’s terminal illness.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Thank You for Playing

results.headline: Review: ‘The Clan’ Presents a Sadist in a Benign Patriarch’s Clothing
results.summary_short: This drama, by Pablo Trapero, depicts a father in 1980s Buenos Aires, who commits crimes as he colludes with Argentina’s military dictatorship.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Clan

results.headline: Review: In ‘Midnight Special,’ on the Run With a Highly Unusual Child
results.summary_short: Jeff Nichols’s film keeps you guessing as you follow two apparent outlaws fleeing federal agents with a young boy who has special talents.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Midnight Special
